@ZackShapiro Only summaries.  I've been meaning to do a deeper dive.  Love the premise.
13/ I'm still an individualist and disagree with him. But recognizing this avoids wasting time and emotional energy and facilitates respect.
12/ We can both write books supporting our own views from all angles, but the differences come down to that one key difference.
11/  I realized that the common thread on everything on which we disagree is he leans a little more collectivist.
10/ On a few specifics, I view his position as fundamentally immoral.  But he's probably a better human being than me; at least as moral.
9/ An example - I'm a passionate individualist.  My brother and I agree on most things, but have some deep disagreements on a few topics.
8/ Most of our logic is a rationalization of our core values, not the other way around.  Mountains of evidence for this.
7/ And useful to realize that our core values (on both morality and metaphysical worldview) seem "accidental."
6/ Debating evidence or logic is valuable, but it's useful to at least occasionally take a huge step back and look at the unstated values.
5/ For example, to a liberal, a conservative referencing the importance of tradition or respect for authority is almost inaudible.
4/ We often talk past one another because there's some unstated core value that we assume that is functionally invisible for others.
3/ In a recent debate on nutrition, the disagreement really came down to a disagreement over the validity of statistical inference.
2/ Haidt's "Righteous Mind" or Sowell's "The Unconstrained Vision" are eye opening frameworks to understand most political debates.
1/ I increasingly find myself focusing on the meta social psychology in debates of all forms.  Politics, religion, nutrition...
